Keywords: split layout, two column auth, auth illustration, auth design
Description: Auth pages use split layout: form on one side, illustration/branding on the other. Maximizes conversion while showing brand identity.
Do: Desktop: 2-column layout (form 50% + illustration 50%). Mobile: form only (hide illustration). Form side: centered, max-w-md. Illustration side: brand colors, product screenshot, or abstract art.
Don't: Don't show illustration on mobile (wastes space). Don't make form area wider than max-w-md. Don't use generic stock photos (use brand-relevant visuals).

Code Example Bad: form stretches entire width

Keywords: signup fields, registration form, create account fields
Description: Sign up forms should collect minimum required information. Reduce friction for conversion.
Do: Essential fields: Full name (or first+last), Email, Password. Optional: Username (if needed). Use single password field + strength indicator (not confirm password). Place OAuth buttons above form with divider.
Don't: Don't ask for phone/address/company at signup (collect later). Don't use confirm password field (use show/hide toggle instead). Don't require username if email is the identifier.
Code Example Good: or
Code Example Bad: <form><input placeholder="First name"/><input placeholder="Last name"/><input placeholder="Username"/><input placeholder="Email"/><input placeholder="Phone"/><input placeholder="Password"/><input placeholder="Confirm password"/></form> <!-- Too many fields -->

Keywords: signin fields, login form, authenticate fields
Description: Sign in forms should be simple: email + password + forgot password link. Minimize friction.
Do: Fields: Email, Password. Links: Forgot password (near password field), Sign up link below form. OAuth buttons above or below form. Optional: Remember me checkbox.
Don't: Don't add CAPTCHA on first attempt (only after failures). Don't hide forgot password link. Don't redirect to homepage on error (stay on form with error message).
Code Example Good: Forgot password?
Code Example Bad: <form><input placeholder="Email"/><input type="password" placeholder="Password"/><button>Login</button></form> <!-- No labels, no forgot password, no styling -->

Keywords: oauth, social login, google login, github login, sso
Description: OAuth/social login buttons for third-party authentication (Google, GitHub, Apple, etc.).
Do: Place OAuth buttons prominently (above or below email form). Use official brand colors/logos. Label: 'Continue with Google' not just icon. Add visual separator between OAuth and email form.
Don't: Don't use custom colors for OAuth buttons (use official brand guidelines). Don't show too many OAuth options (max 3-4). Don't use only icons without text labels. Don't forget loading state on click.

Keywords: form divider, or separator, oauth divider, auth separator
Description: Visual separator between OAuth buttons and email/password form. Common 'or' divider pattern.
Do: Use horizontal line with centered 'or' text. Muted color for line and text. Consistent spacing above and below.
Don't: Don't use 'OR' in caps (too aggressive). Don't use thick lines. Don't skip the divider (confusing which form to use).
Code Example Good: or

Keywords: password strength, password meter, password quality, strong password
Description: Visual indicator showing password strength as user types. Helps users create secure passwords.
Do: Show strength bar below password input. Use colors: red (weak), orange (fair), yellow (good), green (strong). Show text label. Update in real-time. Requirements: min 8 chars, uppercase, number, special char.
Don't: Don't only show after form submission. Don't use only color (add text for accessibility). Don't block form submission for 'fair' passwords (warn but allow).
Code Example Good: Good password
Code Example Bad: Password too weak

Keywords: form error, validation error, input error, error message
Description: Clear error messages positioned near the problem field. Help users fix issues quickly.
Do: Show error message directly below the invalid field. Use red color for error border + message. Use aria-invalid and aria-describedby for accessibility. Clear error when user starts fixing.
Don't: Don't show all errors in a single banner at top (hard to map to fields). Don't only use color (add icon + text). Don't show errors before user interacts with field.
Code Example Good: Please enter a valid email address
Code Example Bad: Error: Invalid email, Invalid password

Keywords: forgot password, reset password, password recovery, email reset
Description: Three-step flow: 1) Enter email, 2) Check email message, 3) Reset password form.
Do: Step 1: Email input + Submit. Step 2: Success message 'Check your email' with resend link. Step 3: New password + confirm password. Each step on its own page/view. Back to Sign In link on all steps.
Don't: Don't confirm whether email exists (security risk). Don't send password in email (send reset link with token). Don't let reset link expire too slowly (15-60 min max).
Code Example Good:
Reset your password

Enter your email and we'll send you a reset link

Back to Sign In
Code Example Bad: Forgot password? Call support at 1-800-XXX

Keywords: email verification, verify email, confirm email, check inbox
Description: After signup, show a page asking user to verify their email. Include resend option.
Do: Show clear message: 'Check your email'. Display the email address used. Include Resend button with cooldown timer. Show 'Wrong email? Change it' link. Auto-redirect after verification.
Don't: Don't auto-login before verification (if email verification is required). Don't make resend button available immediately (add 30-60s cooldown). Don't lose user's signup data if they navigate away.
Code Example Good:
Check your email

We sent a verification link to user@example.com
Code Example Bad: Please verify your email.

Keywords: 2fa, two factor, mfa, otp, verification code, authenticator
Description: Two-factor authentication code input page. Usually 6-digit code from authenticator app or SMS.
Do: Use 6 individual input boxes (OTP pattern). Auto-focus next box on input. Auto-submit when all 6 digits entered. Show 'Use recovery code' link. Allow paste of full code.
Don't: Don't use a single long input for OTP (individual boxes feel more natural). Don't block paste functionality. Don't forget backup/recovery code option.
Code Example Good:
Two-factor authentication

Enter the 6-digit code from your authenticator app

Use a recovery code instead
Code Example Bad: <input placeholder="Enter 2FA code" class="w-full" /> <!-- Single input, no visual guidance -->

Keywords: terms, privacy, consent, agreement, legal checkbox
Description: Sign up forms should include a terms/privacy acceptance mechanism.
Do: Place below password field, above submit button. Link to Terms and Privacy Policy (open in new tab). Use checkbox or implicit consent text. Text: 'By signing up, you agree to our Terms and Privacy Policy'.
Don't: Don't pre-check the checkbox (user must actively agree). Don't put terms text in a modal. Don't use legal jargon in the checkbox label.
Code Example Bad: <!-- No terms/privacy mention at signup --> <button>Create Account</button>

Keywords: auth navigation, login signup link, switch auth, auth redirect
Description: Sign In and Sign Up pages must link to each other prominently. Users often land on the wrong one.
Do: Sign In: 'Don't have an account? Sign up' below form. Sign Up: 'Already have an account? Sign in' below form. Use contrasting link color. Place after submit button.
Don't: Don't hide the cross-link. Don't use ambiguous text ('Go back'). Don't remove cross-links on mobile.
Code Example Good: Don't have an account? Sign up for free
Code Example Bad: <!-- Sign In page ends with just the form, no link to Sign Up --> <!-- Users have no way to navigate to registration -->

Keywords: redirect after login, auth redirect, post login, return url
Description: After successful authentication, redirect user to the appropriate page based on context.
Do: Redirect to: dashboard (default), or previous page (if user was redirected to login). Store return URL in query param (?redirect=/settings). Show loading/transition during redirect.
Don't: Don't redirect to homepage after login (go to dashboard/app). Don't lose the return URL on page refresh. Don't show blank page during redirect.
Code Example Good: // After successful auth: const redirectTo = searchParams.get('redirect') || '/dashboard'; router.push(redirectTo);
Code Example Bad: // Always redirect to homepage: router.push('/'); // Lost context of where user was trying to go

Keywords: show password, toggle password, password visibility, eye icon
Description: Toggle button to show/hide password text in password input fields.
Do: Use eye/eye-off icon button inside the input field (right side). Toggle between type='password' and type='text'. Add aria-label. Don't auto-hide after timeout.
Don't: Don't use a separate checkbox for show/hide. Don't move the toggle button outside the input. Don't forget to update the icon when toggling.

Keywords: auth social proof, signup trust, registration confidence
Description: Show social proof elements on auth pages to build trust and encourage signup.
Do: Display on illustration side: user count ('Join 10,000+ users'), company logos ('Trusted by'), testimonial quote, or product screenshot. Keep subtle, don't distract from form.
Don't: Don't clutter the form side with social proof. Don't show fake numbers. Don't use too many elements (1-2 max).
Code Example Good:
This tool saved our team 20 hours per week

Sarah J., CTO at TechCo

Trusted by 10,000+ developers worldwide
Code Example Bad: <!-- Auth page with no social proof, just a blank form --> <!-- Missed opportunity to build trust -->

Keywords: auth loading, submit loading, login loading, signup spinner
Description: Show loading state when auth form is submitted. Prevent double submission.
Do: Disable submit button during request. Show spinner inside button. Change button text: 'Sign in' → 'Signing in...'. Maintain button width (don't let it shrink). Re-enable on error.
Don't: Don't redirect before getting API response. Don't allow form re-submission during loading. Don't show a full-page spinner (keep it in the button).
Code Example Good: <button disabled class="w-full bg-blue-600 text-white py-3 rounded-lg flex items-center justify-center gap-2 opacity-75 cursor-not-allowed"><svg class="animate-spin w-5 h-5">spinner</svg>Signing in...</button>
Code Example Bad: <button>Sign in</button> <!-- No loading state, user clicks multiple times -->

Keywords: auth error, login error, wrong password, account locked
Description: Clear and helpful error messages for authentication failures.
Do: Show error inline (below form or above fields). Use red background with icon. Be specific but not too detailed: 'Invalid email or password' (not 'Password incorrect' which reveals email exists). Clear error on new attempt.
Don't: Don't reveal whether email exists in system ('Email not found' → security issue). Don't show technical errors to users. Don't persist error message after user starts correcting.
Code Example Good: Invalid email or password. Please try again.
Code Example Bad: Error 401: Unauthorized

Keywords: auth nav, login navigation, minimal header auth
Description: Auth pages should have minimal navigation to keep users focused on conversion.
Do: Show only: Logo (links to home), and optionally a 'Help' or 'Contact' link. No full site navigation. No footer navigation.
Don't: Don't show full site navigation on auth pages (distracts from conversion). Don't remove logo entirely (users need to know where they are). Don't add promotional banners.
Code Example Good: LogoNeed help?
Code Example Bad: LogoFeaturesPricingBlogAboutContact
